brief_summary.textblock:
Analgesia after cesarean section is still not satisfactory for many women. Even if pain
      reduction is sufficient with the technique of intrathecal morphine injection, side effects
      such as nausea and pruritus are common.

      Since several years, an alternative technique has been studied, the "transversus abdominis
      plane (TAP)"-block. Here a local anesthetic is injected in the abdominal wall muscles, and
      this has been shown to give a similar analgesic effect compared to intrathecal morphine,
      with potentially less side effects.

      With this study, we want to evaluate if the TAP-block yields indeed less side effects when
      compared with intrathecal morphine.

      The study will be a prospective study with the patients randomized to either a group with
      intrathecal morphine or a group with TAP-block.

clinical_study.brief_title: Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) Block Versus Intrathecal Morphine for Caesarean Section - Randomised Controlled Trial

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        Subjects must satisfy all of the following criteria to be enrolled into the study:

          -  American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) physical status less than 3 Able to read and
             understand the information sheet and to sign and date the consent form

          -  Scheduled for elective C-section planned with spinal anaesthesia

          -  Age>18

        Exclusion Criteria:

        Potential subjects who meet any of the following criteria will be excluded from
        participating in the study:

          -  Complicated pregnancy defined as having preeclampsia or placenta accreta, increta and
             percreta.

          -  Drug addiction.

          -  Contraindication to spinal anaesthesia (history of clotting disorders, septicemia,
             local infection at the injection site, spinal malformation, elevated intracranial
             pressure)

          -  Contraindication to TAP block (skin infection, abdominal wall muscle defect such as
             hernia and previous abdominal wall mesh).

          -  BMI>40 kg/m2

          -  Weight less than 50 kg the day of the C-section.

          -  Height less than 150 cm or more than 175 cm.

          -  Allergy/contraindication to any medication used in the study.

          -  Previous median abdominal incision. Necessity to perform the C-section urgently
             before the scheduled date (with less than 24h preparation time).

intervention.description: in addition to the standard spinal anesthesia drugs (bupivacaine and fentanyl), morphine is added

clinical_study.official_title: Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) Block Versus Intrathecal Morphine for Caesarean Section - Randomised Controlled Trial

primary_outcome.description: Data for this endpoint will be gathered at 6h and 24h postoperatively from nurses' records in the recovery room (at 6h) and on the ward (at 24h), and counterchecked by asking the patient
primary_outcome.measure: cumulative incidence of nausea and/or vomiting at 24 hours

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: inquired directly from the patient at 6 and 24h
(inquired directly from the patient at 6 and 24h).
secondary_outcome.measure: Cumulative incidence of treated nausea and vomiting at 24h

secondary_outcome.description: Sedation defined as an observer's assessment of alertness and sedation (OAAS) score lower than 4
secondary_outcome.measure: Cumulative incidence of sedation at 6 and 24h.

secondary_outcome.description: defined as a systolic blood pressure of less than 100 mmHg for longer than 5 minutes (from nurse records at 6 and 24h)
defined as a heart rate of less than 50/min for longer than 5 minutes (from nurse records at 6 and 24h)
defined as a respiratory frequency of less than 8/min for longer than 5 minutes (from nurse records at 6 and 24h
(recorded in the memory of the patient controlled analgesia (PCA) pump).
(recorded in the memory of the PCA pump

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain score at rest at 24 and 48 hours postoperatively

secondary_outcome.description: at 24 and 48 hours postoperatively (using the numerical rating scale (NRS 0-10)).
measured on a numeric rating scale and with the questionnaire "quality of recovery" (QoR40)
secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal satisfaction at 24 and 48 hours postoperatively
